1. Start tomcat using startup.bat
2. Minimize tomcat console
3. Do either of the following:
   a) Request http://localhost:8080/ using Internet Explorer, or
   b) Stop tomcat using shutdown.bat (from either another console or double-
clicking)
4. PC resets and reboots

This problem exists in 4.0 and 4.01. If the tomcat console window has focus, 
this problem does not occur.

text:
I think something is wacked in my system because I just tried an older (3.2.2) 
installation on my system and the same thing happened. This use to work for me 
with no problems.

However, when I go into the jakarta-tomcat-4.0.1\bin directory in a console and 
start tomcat using:

c:\jakarta-tomcat-4.0.1\bin\catalina.bat run

No problems. Go figure.

You are correct -- there is *definitely* something whacked up with your system.

If you are running Tomcat out-of-the-box (i.e. no native code), then a system
reboot is a symptom of one (or more) of the following, not a Tomcat bug:
* Hardware problem
* OS problem
* JDK problem

Pure-Java programs cannot cause a system reboot (or even a JDK crash) without
one of these factors being the underlying cause.  Therefore, I'm closing this as
a Tomcat bug report, and suggest you investigate the above three areas.
creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
bojan@binarix.com
text:
Just FYI, since 'PC resets and reboots', this cannot be a JDK issue either (ie.
JDK didn't shut down the system gracefully, it crashed). So, don't go on a JDK
downloading spree because you might get a different JDK that will (accidentally)
work, but the underlying cause of the crash is still going to be HW/OS combo. A
disaster waiting to happen...
